## 1. What a 5‑G Cellular Network Looks Like  

| Component | What it does | Typical frequency range | Typical power output |
|----------|--------------|--------------------------|----------------------|
| **Macro‑cell tower** (the “big” tower you see on highways) | Provides wide‑area coverage, connects many users simultaneously, and links the network to the core‑network backbone. | 600 MHz – 6 GHz (low‑band & mid‑band) | Up to 20–40 W effective isotropic radiated power (EIRP) for a sector, but the actual transmitted power is usually a few watts because the antenna gain is high. |
| **Small cell / micro‑cell / pico‑cell** (often mounted on street‑lamps, building facades) | Fills coverage gaps, boosts capacity in dense urban areas, and enables the very high‑frequency “mmWave” bands that have limited range. | 24 GHz – 40 GHz (mmWave) and sometimes 3.5 GHz (mid‑band) | Typically ≤ 1 W EIRP (often < 0.1 W). |
| **Base‑band unit & radio unit** (inside the tower or at the base of a small cell) | Generates the digital signal, modulates it onto the radio carrier, and handles hand‑overs, scheduling, etc. | – | – |
| **Back‑haul** (fiber or microwave link) | Carries the aggregated traffic to the wider internet / operator core. | – | – |

### Key Technical Features of 5G

| Feature | Why it matters for the RF field | How it changes the “exposure” picture |
|---------|--------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| **Higher carrier frequencies** (up to ~ 39 GHz for commercial deployments, with research prototypes up to 100 GHz) | Higher frequencies have shorter wavelengths (≈ 5 mm at 60 GHz). | Energy is absorbed in the very outer layers of skin (≈ 0.5 mm depth). Penetration into deeper tissues is less than for lower‑frequency bands. |
| **Beamforming / massive MIMO** | Antennas with many elements can steer narrow beams toward a device rather than broadcasting omnidirectionally. | The instantaneous power density in the direction of the beam can be higher than a traditional sector antenna, but the beam spends only a fraction of a second on any given spot, and the average exposure over time remains low. |
| **Small‑cell densification** | More cells placed closer together to compensate for the limited range of mmWave. | Each individual transmitter operates at lower power because the distance to the user is short. The overall “ambient” RF level in a dense urban area is the sum of many low‑power sources. |
| **Time‑division duplex (TDD)** | Uplink and downlink share the same frequency band, alternating in time. | Users’ devices also transmit, contributing a small amount of RF exposure (typically < 0.1 W). |

---

## 2. How Exposure is Quantified  

| Metric | Definition | Typical regulatory limit (general public) |
|--------|------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **Power density (S)** | Energy per unit area (W/m²). Relevant for frequencies ≥ 6 GHz where the wavelength is small compared to the body. | 10 W/m² (ICNIRP, FCC) for frequencies 2–300 GHz. |
| **Specific Absorption Rate (SAR)** | Rate at which RF energy is absorbed per unit mass of tissue (W/kg). Used for frequencies ≤ 6 GHz where the field penetrates deeper. | 2 W/kg (averaged over 10 g of tissue) in the US; 4 W/kg (averaged over 10 g) in Europe. |
| **Reference levels for whole‑body exposure** | 0.08 W/kg (ICNIRP) for the whole body, based on thermal effects. | Same as above. |

## 1. Regulatory Power‑Density Limits that Matter for 5 G  

| Authority | Frequency range covered | Limit for **general public** (continuous exposure) | How the limit is expressed |
|-----------|------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------|
| **ICNIRP (International Commission on Non‑Ionising Radiation Protection)** | 2 GHz – 300 GHz (including all 5 G bands) | **10 W · m⁻²** | Power density (S) measured at the surface of a body or a probe placed in the far‑field of the source. |
| **FCC (U.S. Federal Communications Commission)** | 6 GHz – 300 GHz | **10 W · m⁻²** (same numeric value; the FCC’s “Maximum Permissible Exposure” is derived from the same basic thermal‑heating model) | Same as ICNIRP. |
| **Health Canada / European Union (EN‑IEC 62209‑1)** | 2 GHz – 300 GHz | 10 W · m⁻² (EU) | Identical to ICNIRP. |

> **Bottom line:** For the frequencies used by 5 G (most notably the 3.5 GHz mid‑band and the 24–39 GHz mmWave band) the **legal ceiling is 10 W/m²** for the general public. This limit is set so that, even if a person were standing right next to a continuously radiating source for many hours, the temperature rise in the skin would be less than 0.1 °C – a level that the body can easily dissipate.

---

## 2. What a “Typical” 5 G Small Cell on a Street Lamp Looks Like  

| Parameter | Typical value (based on commercial deployments in Europe, North America, and Asia) |
|-----------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Transmit power (EIRP)** | 0.1 W – 1 W (most operators quote ≤ 1 W EIRP for mmWave small cells; for the 3.5 GHz band the EIRP can be a few watts because the antenna gain is lower). |
| **Antenna gain** | 15 dBi – 25 dBi (high‑gain arrays that enable narrow beams). |
| **Physical height** | 4 m – 8 m above ground (mounted on lamp‑post, traffic‑light pole, or building façade). |
| **Beam‑steering capability** | Up to 60° × 60° field‑of‑view, with individual sub‑beams that can be as narrow as 10°–15°. |
| **Duty cycle (average “on‑time” for a given spot)** | Typically **≤ 5 %** for any fixed point on the ground because the beam follows moving user devices; the average over a 1‑second interval is often < 0.1 W/m² (see calculations below). |

---

## 3. From Transmit Power to Power‑Density at Ground Level  

### 3.1. Simplified far‑field formula  

When you are **far enough** from the antenna that the wave front is essentially planar (the *far‑field* distance \(R_{ff}\) ≈ 2 D²/λ, where D is the largest antenna dimension), the power density is

\[
S = \frac{\text{EIRP}}{4\pi r^{2}} \quad \text{[W·m}^{-2}\text{]},
\]

where  

* **EIRP** = effective isotropic radiated power (W).  
* **r** = distance from the antenna (m).  

### 3.2. Example: 3.5 GHz small cell, 1 W EIRP  

| Distance from antenna | Calculated \(S\) (W/m²) | How it compares to the 10 W/m² limit |
|-----------------------|--------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| 1 m (directly underneath, line‑of‑sight) | \(S = \frac{1}{4\pi(1)^{2}} \approx 0.08\) | **0.8 %** of the limit |
| 3 m (typical sidewalk distance) | \(S \approx 0.009\)

## 1. What “Beam‑Steering” Means in a 5 G Small Cell  

| Concept | How it is realized in hardware | What it does to the radiated field |
|---------|--------------------------------|------------------------------------|
| **Phased‑array antenna** | An array of many (typically 8‑64) identical radiating elements, each fed by a separate RF channel. The signal to each element is given a precise **phase shift** (and sometimes a small amplitude tweak). | When the phases are chosen correctly, the individual wavelets add constructively in one direction and destructively elsewhere. The result is a **narrow, high‑gain beam** that can be pointed anywhere inside the array’s field‑of‑view (usually a few tens of degrees in azimuth and elevation). |
| **Digital beam‑forming** | The phase‑shift values are generated in a digital signal‑processor (DSP) or FPGA and updated every few hundred microseconds to a few milliseconds. | The beam can **track a moving user device** (smartphone, tablet, vehicle) with a latency of < 10 ms, keeping the user inside the high‑gain main lobe while the rest of the surrounding space sees only the much lower sidelobe level. |
| **Multi‑user MIMO (MU‑MIMO)** | The same array can create **separate beams** for several users at the same time, each beam having its own set of phase‑shift values (the DSP solves a linear‑algebra problem called “precoding”). | The total radiated power is **shared** among the active beams, so the power density of any *single* beam is lower than it would be if the whole EIRP were dumped into one direction. |
| **Dynamic power control** | The base‑band software continuously monitors the radio link quality (signal‑to‑noise ratio, error rate, etc.). If the link is strong, it reduces the transmit power; if the link degrades, it raises the power just enough to maintain the target data rate. | The **instantaneous EIRP** can vary from a few milliwatts up to the maximum rated value (e.g., 1 W) but, on average, it stays well below the maximum because most users are only a few meters away and the channel is good. |

### Visual picture

```

            │ 5G Base‑band    │
            └─────┬─────┬─────┘
                  │     │
          (digital)   (RF)  →  Phased‑array panel (≈ 30 cm × 30 cm)
                  │
            ┌─────▼─────┐
            │  Beam‑forming DSP  │
            └─────┬─────┘
                  │   (updates phase set‑points every 0.5‑2 ms)
   ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────►
  Narrow high‑gain beam (≈ 10°‑15° width) sweeps across users
```

## 2. Why Beam‑Steering Does **Not** Increase Average Exposure  

### 2.1. Two “time‑averaging” steps are built into the exposure calculation  

| Step | What is averaged | Typical averaging interval used by safety guidelines |
|------|------------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| **(a) Beam‑on time for a *given point* on the ground** | The beam may point at that point for a few milliseconds while a user passes by, then it points elsewhere. | The **ICNIRP/FCC** reference level for power density is defined for **continuous exposure** (i.e., a *steady‑state* value). To compare a pulsed or scanning source to the limit, you must **average the power density over a period long enough that the thermal response of the tissue can follow** – usually **6 minutes** for whole‑body exposure and **30 seconds** for local skin exposure. |
| **(b) Population‑wide averaging** | In a street with many people, each person experiences a different instantaneous beam pattern. The average over many people (or over many seconds for a single person) is the relevant metric for a *general‑public* limit. | The same 6‑minute / 30‑second windows are used; the limits are set so that **any individual** who stays in the same spot for that duration cannot exceed the thermal‑rise threshold. |
